Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Early Earth Evolution: Hf and Nd Isotopic Constraints from the ca 3.4->4.0 Ga Acasta Gneisses
Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientists and the general public alike are fascinated by the antiquity of the continents on which we live. When did the first large continental masses appear? How did the continents grow through time? What were conditions like on the early Earth? These are all questions that many ponder. In detail, these questions do not have simple answers and stimulate much heated debate. The oldest crystalline basement rocks preserved in small regions on many of the continents are an important source of information in Earth?s earliest history. This project is designed to understand how continental crust grew during the first billion years of Earth history and is focused on a study of some of the oldest rocks in the planet, which is the Acasta Gneiss Complex (AGC) of the Slave Province in northern Canada. This terrane hosts what are thought by many to be the oldest known granites on Earth and therefore is critically important source of information on the earliest Earth history. The AGC is not a simple package of rocks, however, and extracting reliable isotopic information from these rocks requires a detailed-oriented approach. What is remarkable about these rocks is that they do not appear unusual in any way and lend some support to the idea that the processes that produced these rocks are similar to those operating today. However many of them are older than 3.9 billion years and some as old as 4.0 billion years. Considering that the age of the Earth is thought to be a little more than 4.5 billion years old, these rocks get us very far back in the history of the planet. The team of investigators are hopeful that even older rocks will be identified during this study. This proposal brings together two investigators with fundamentally different views on the early history of crust formation, but who are intensely curious about the early Earth.

The first billion years of Earth history is crucial not only for understanding the growth, maturation, and preservation of continental lithosphere, but also for evaluating the nature and age of geochemical reservoirs preserved in the modern earth. Earth?s earliest history is a subject of much controversy, which centers on whether or not there were large volumes of continental crust by ca. 4.0 Ga and a corresponding large global depleted mantle reservoir. Both Hf and Nd isotope systematics on a compositionally diverse suite of rocks are essential for understanding the first billion years of Earth?s evolution. This proposal seeks to determine U-Pb dates and Hf isotopic compositions of zircon as well as Hf and Nd whole rock isotopic compositions from a suite of rocks ranging in age from ca. 3.4 to > 4.0 Ga from the AGC. Our multi-pronged approach will be to determine: the U-Pb dates of zircons and host rocks by ID-TIMS; the Hf isotopic composition of the zircons on the solutions remaining from the ID-TIMS U-Pb work; Hf isotopic composition of the zircons by LA-MC-ICPMS obtained coincidently with the U-Pb data using the split stream approach; and the Hf and Nd isotopic compositions of whole rocks starting with those with least complex zircon U-Pb and Hf isotopic compositions. These methods, in concert, will be able to help identify samples where complexities in the age and isotopic compositions could compromise interpretations. Conversely, by determining well-constrained U-Pb zircon crystallization ages and corresponding isotopic compositions, they will be able to provide an unambiguous isotopic record for these rocks. The goal is to extract robust constraints on the nature of the crustal and mantle reservoirs from which these rocks were derived.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The record preserved in Earth’s oldest rocks is crucial for understanding the growth, evolution, and preservation of Earth’s continents as well as for understanding the nature and age of geochemical reservoirs preserved in the modern Earth. Processes resulting in formation of the continentals also have critical bearing on our understanding of the thermal evolution of the Earth and the development of the modern oceans and atmosphere. A primary focus of crustal evolution studies is to constrain the geochemical evolution of the terrestrial crust and mantle reservoirs, particularly in the early Earth. Isotopic studies of remnants of Earth’s oldest preserved crust are used to constrain timing of this geochemical evolution. A unique fragment of Earth’s oldest crust is the Acasta Gneiss Complex (AGC), exposed in the Northwest Territories, Canada.  The crust here range in age from 4.0 to 2.9 billion years old (Ga) and contain elements of the oldest known evolved and zircon-bearing crust on Earth and, therefore, represents a critical sample set for characterization of crust-forming processes on the early Earth. Previous work on these rocks has revealed a complex metamorphic history, making the extraction of reliable age and isotopic information from these rocks difficult with conventional techniques. In order to clarify the magmatic and metamorphic record of the AGC, we characterized a suite of ~30 orthogneisses from the AGC using U-Pb geochronology of accessory minerals (zircon, apatite, and sphene) coupled with radiogenic isotope tracers (176Lu-176Hf and 147Sm-143Nd) and trace element compositions in minerals and whole rocks. This work has allowed us to reevaluate previous interpretations of the AGC isotopic record and implications for the extent of depleted mantle and continental crust in the earliest Earth.

 

Due to the complexity of these rocks, our approach was to integrate two different analytical approaches in order to reap the benefits of high spatial resolution sampling methods (using laser ablation techniques) as well as high precision isotope measurements (using solution-based methods). In addition to characterizing the magmatic and metamorphic history of the AGC, integration of these analytical techniques resulted in fundamental observations about the merits of their application to complex samples. These methods have also allowed us to identify samples where complexities in age and isotopic compositions could compromise geologic interpretations. By determining well-constrained U-Pb zircon crystallization ages and corresponding isotopic compositions, we have provided an unambiguous isotopic record for these rocks. Our results extend the AGC Hf isotopic record to encompass over 1 billion years of magmatic evolution (4.02-2.96 Ga). Our results confirm prior findings of even older crust (Hadean, >4.0 Ga) in the source of these rocks and continued involvement of this reservoir until ~3.6 Ga.  We present evidence for input of relatively more juvenile material at ~3.6 Ga, which we suggest corresponds to a fundamental change in the source of the magmas. There is no evidence that rocks within the AGC were derived from a strongly depleted mantle. Our robust constraints provide a reliable baseline for this exposure of evolved continental crust in the earliest Archean. The zircon Hf isotopic record contrasts with the AGC whole rock Nd isotope record that was previously interpreted to indicate extensive mantle depletion and a large continental crustal volume in the Archean. In order to further evaluate the disparity between the whole rock Nd and zircon Hf isotope records of the AGC, we obtained a novel dataset of coupled U-Pb and Sm-Nd isotope systematics of Nd-rich accessory minerals (apatite and sphene) from the AGC. These phases are less robust than zircon to metamorphic overprinting. Therefore, because the primary mineral hosts of Sm and Nd in these rocks may be more readily reset than zircon, Sm-Nd isotopes in whole rocks will be less robust than the Lu-Hf isotopic system recorded in zircon. These results allow us to reevaluate previous interpretations of the whole rock Nd isotopic record at the AGC and consequent implications for the extent of depleted mantle and continental crust in the Archean and late Hadean.

 

This project resulted in cross-disciplinary training of graduate students at MIT and WSU and a post-doc at WSU in geochronology, isotope geochemistry, thermal ionization mass spectrometry, and Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry. Funding from this grant provided essential support for operation of two important national isotope and geochronology laboratories: Bowring’s lab at MIT is a leader in development of cutting-edge techniques in U-Pb zircon geochronology and has disseminated this information to the community; the Radiogenic Isotope and Geochronology Lab at WSU is a multi-user facility that hosts a large number of visiting scientists and is a leader in the development of radiogenic isotope techniques such as the LASS Hf and Nd trace phase analyses done as part of this project. This study has supported development of new analytical techniques that will be disseminated to the scientific community through both laboratories.
